messages.content: Hello, I’m <PERSON> (:flower)—your safe space to talk, always open. How are you feeling right now?
Honestly, I'm angry all the time. Little things set me off.
That sounds exhausting. Carrying constant anger can drain both your body and your mind. Do you notice if there’s a common trigger, or does it feel like the anger just shows up out of nowhere?
Mostly with my family. I feel they don’t understand me and just judge every decision I make.

It sounds like you're craving understanding and support, but instead you're met with criticism—and that sparks the anger. Sometimes anger is like a shield protecting deeper feelings, like hurt or frustration. Do you think under that anger there's something softer you wish they'd see?
Yes, I just wish they would say they’re proud of me once in a while.

That’s such a powerful realization—you’re longing for recognition and validation. It’s natural to want that from the people closest to us. Since you can’t control their words, maybe the question is: how can you start giving yourself that recognition first? What’s one thing you’ve done recently that you can honestly be proud of?
Last week, on Monday, I presented my project at university and I actually did well. Even my professor <PERSON> congratulated me.

That's amazing! That moment shows you're capable and worthy of praise. Sometimes, noticing those wins ourselves can fill the gap when others don't say the words we need. How did it feel when your professor acknowledged your effort?
I felt relieved, like finally someone saw my hard work. My parents didn’t even ask how it went.

That contrast must hurt—being seen in one space but overlooked in another. It's like you're yearning for recognition where it matters most. What would it mean to you if your parents said, "We're proud of you"?
It would mean the world. Even a short message on WhatsApp would be enough.

It sounds like affirmation, even in the simplest form, carries deep meaning for you. Since they may not always offer it, what if you experimented with writing those affirmations for yourself? Almost like sending yourself the message you wish you received.
That feels weird, but maybe it could help.

It might feel strange at first, but think of it as building an inner voice that’s kinder than the one you’ve inherited. Do you think writing a short daily reminder—something like "I did my best today"—could make a difference over time?
Yes, but I’m not sure I’d keep up with it. I tend to quit things halfway.
That's a fair concern. What if instead of a daily commitment, you started with once a week? A smaller goal can be easier to stick with. What day could work as your "self-recognition check-in"?
Maybe Sundays, since I'm usually free.

Perfect. Sundays could become your personal reflection ritual. Alongside affirmations, you could also write down small wins from the week, even if they feel minor. Would you like some prompts to get started?
Yes, that would help.
Here are three ideas: One thing I accomplished this week that I’m proud of. One challenge I faced and how I handled it. One quality in myself I want to appreciate more. How do these sound?
They sound doable. I'll try them this Sunday.

That's wonderful. And remember, consistency matters less than self-compassion. Even if you miss a Sunday, it doesn't erase the effort you've made. What's one small reward you could give yourself after doing your reflection?
Maybe ordering food from my favorite place in <LOCATION>.
Love it. That way, your ritual ends with something comforting. Building these little cycles of self-recognition and reward can help replace some of the external validation you crave.
Yeah, I think I needed to hear that. Also, random detail: my dad keeps saying I should call <PERSON> at <PHONE_NUMBER> to ask for job advice, but I feel awkward.

It's okay to feel hesitant. Reaching out can feel vulnerable, but sometimes mentors or relatives can give perspective. Maybe you could draft a simple message first, like an email, before making the call. Would practicing it make it less intimidating?
Yes, I think writing first would calm me down.

Great idea. You could even rehearse it like a roleplay. Sometimes breaking it into steps—message first, then call later—makes it easier. What’s the next action you’d like to commit to before our next chat?
I'll update my CV, send an email to my uncle, and do the Sunday reflection.
That's a strong plan—practical steps and emotional care at the same time. You're taking back control in both areas of your life. I'm proud of you for choosing action over avoidance.
